STATE OF NEBRASKA Twenty-third Biennial Report OFTHK Superintendent OF THE Nebraska Hospital for the Insane LINCOLN, NEBRASKA Tc the Governor and the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions For the Bennium ending November 30, 1916

OFFICERS B. F. Williams _ Superintendent L. B. PlLSBURY First Assistant Physician H. L. Ewing Second Assistant Physician F. S. Marnell Pathologist J. R. Helms Steward Margaret Helms Matron H. L. O'Connor Bookkeeper NON-RESIDENT Frederick A. Stuff Chaplain Clarence Emerson Consulting: Pathologist

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 239 NEBRASKA HOSPITAL FOR THE INSANE Lincoln, Nebraska To His Excellency, Honorable John H. Morehead, Govemot , and to the Honorable members of the Board of Commis - sioners of State Institutions, Howard Kennedy, Henry Gerdes and Silas A. Holcomb: Gentlemen: The Nebraska Hospital for the Insane at Lincoln came into existence in the year 1870, and on the 26th day of that year the first patient was received. Since that time there has been a steady increase in the demands on the institution. The development of the institution has not kept pace with the demands so that in this year the institution is wholly in - adequate to care for the district. The receiving district assigned to this institution com - prises fourteen counties in the southeast portion of the state. The aggregate population of which is approximately one-half the total population of the entire State. The following reports and statistical tables comprise the twenty-third biennial report of the Nebraska Hospital for the Insane at Lincoln. This report embraces the period be - ginning December 1, 1914, and ending November 30, 1916. The population of this hospital on the first day of December, 1914, was 724 patients, 325 male and 399 female. There were admitted 449 male and 230 female patients during this bien - nial period. We have discharged from the hospital 366 male and 144 female patients. 69 male and 74 female patients have died. There were in the hospital on the 30th day of November, 1916, 336 male and 415 female, or a total of 751 patients. The daily average population of the hospital has been 734 and there has been a total of 1414 patients under treatment durintr the biennial period.

240 I Because of our crowded condition 117 male and 35 nale patients committed from this district were received the hospital at Norfolk and 27 male and 4 female patients re received by the hospital at Ingleside, or a total of 183 :ients committed from this district during the biennial •iod received by other hospitals because of our inability receive them. There have been committed to hospitals for i insane from this district during the biennial period a al of 862 patients, 679 of which were received at this hos - al and 183 of which were received by hospitals outside the HOUSING I At the close of the last biennial period attention was lied to the fact that 188 single beds and 83 three-quarter ds comprised the housing equipment in the male division the hospital. That 319 single beds and 53 three-quarter ds comprised the equipment in the female division of the spital. Our report revealed the fact that there was present the hospital on this date 325 men and 399 women. We ;re then meeting the situation by sleeping two patients to three-quarter bed. On the female side a few additional ds have been provided by an extension to the sleeping rch, but our increase in patients has occupied these addi - mal beds and the situation in the female division is essen - illy the same as it was two years ago. In the male division s fire-proof addition will afford 75 additional beds. When e building is completed it will relieve the congestion now isting and will enable us to give each patient in the male .ision a single bed, but by so doing we will be forced to fuse admission to new patients much as we have done ring the present biennial period. (The increase in the number of insane in institutions seems bear direct ratio to the increased capacity. Improvement institutional administration and higher intelligence on the rt of the people with reference to state institutions have ■noved the aversion which has always existed toward com - ttinflf insane to state care. Thus, the increase in insanity perhaps more apparent than real, yet it cannot be denied

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 241 that certain forces making for feeble-mindedness and mental overthrow continue without abatement. Steps will be taken by this State to control the use of alcohol. A move has been made toward regulating the birth rate among the insane, feeble-minded and all persons unfit to procreate. If now in addition to these, syphillis may in some manner be subject to state control, there will result a definite reduction in the number of mental cases in the years to come. How - ever, the complexity of our present day civilization makes such demands on the individual that those to whom have been bequeathed unstable nervous systems become yearly more liable to mental overthrow by reason of the increased strain to which they are subject; and further, such an indi - vidual reacting- somewhat abnormally becomes less able to meet the requirements of a more critical and ever advancing public censorship. Therefore, while on the one hand we may hope by appropriate legislation to diminish the number of insane and feeble-minded, we are on the other hand increas - ing the strain and raising the standard of individual conduct so that abnormal individuals are more liable to require the protection of state institutions. ACCOMPLISHMENTS During the biennial period special attention has been given to the development of the industrial department; the effort being to provide every patient with some form of oc - cupational pursuit. The wisdom of this procedure is obvious. Patients are made more happy and in many instances actually improve mentally by reason of having certain tasks to perform. We regard industrial pursuits as one of our most potent therapeutic agents. Amusements and Library We cannot afford to overlook the amusement and enter - tainment feature of our patients' lives. We have developed the library department by converting a portion of the large amusement hall into a library room. Each afternoon at three o'clock patients assemble in this library, make their own se - lections of books, choose their reading periodicals or listen

242 SECOND BIENNIAL REPORT OF to readings given by the librarian. On Tuesday evening the moving picture show is given ; each Friday night a patients' dance. An occasional entertainment is secured outside of these and the large amusement hall is quite generally occupied. During the day time when not used for these purposes it is made to serve as a gymnasium. Tennis, basketball, volley - ball are some of the games played in this hall. Religious Service Religious services are held each Sunday morning at nine - thirty. The institution orchestra and choir made up of per - sons connected with the institution supply the music. Dr. Stuff, our chaplain, conducts the services and the hour of chapel service is most profitable. Medical Treatment In the medical treatment of patients there is nothing new in the literature with reference to the treatment of the insane, which influences results at this time. The prompt recognition of syphilis by serological examination together with the clinical symptoms has simplified diagnosis and has enabled us to render a more definite prognosis in many of our early cases. The use of hydrotherapy continues to be a popular method of treatment and has given excellent results when judiciously applied. The literature in psychiatry con - tains no startling revelations during the past two-years' period. The influence of more extensive application of meth - ods of treatment directed especially toward syphilis has re - sulted in a more conservative attitude with reference to the efficiency of vigorous anti-syphilitic treatment in paresis. Dementia praecox constitutes our largest group of admis - sions. Nothing has been revealed during this period which would suggest a new conception of this disease or afford new methods of treatment. Epileptic patients continue to be received and quite generally improved under institutional treatment. Much agitation concerning the relation of in - testinal stasis to epilepsy has resulted in general observation by a large number of investigators. From those who have observed these cases and the application of surgical proced-

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 243 ure, we glean the impression that this plan of surgical treat - ment bears no greater results than any other surgical pro - cedure directed to any portion of the human anatomy. Per - sons having to do with the epileptics have long since observed that a surgical procedure of any sort requiring a general anaesthetic very often results in cessation of seizures for a variable length of time. However, every effort should be directed toward the correction of any physiological error and the fact that surgical procedure does influence seizures even temporarily suggests very strongly the influence of internal secretions in producing or influencing epileptic seizures. Re - search should be most vigorous in all state institutions. An expenditure of money to provide for a research laboratory would enable Nebraska institutions to speak more definitely of much of the literature with reference to mental diseases. Dipsomania A narcotic ward for the treatment of inebriety was es - tablished by the legislaure of 1905. There was no specific equipment or housing facilities provided. The law contem - plated an isolated structure and it specifically provides that patients shall not be housed on the ward with the insane. This feature of the law has been ignored throughout the entire history of the narcotic ward in this institution. On the female side there are rarely more than two or three patients committed at one time, hence it would be entirely impossible to maintain a ward for two or three patients with special dining room service and equipment. In the male division of the hospital the entire capacity of the institution is not sufficient to care for the insane. However, we do re - cieve urgent cases of dipsomania. Social Scrrice In view of the large and increasing number of paroled and discharged patients who continue to live outside institu - tions, the state having an interest in continuing such patients on parole should employ a field worker whose duties will bring the worker in contact with the patient and his home life in such manner as to provide the hospital with the actual in-

244 SECOND BIENNIAL REPORT OF Imation concerning home environment, social or domestic luence having a bearing on the mental attitude of the case. K), making it possible to extend aid in the way of advice those threatened with mental overthrow and to instruct atives and friends with reference to the management of •oled patients or incipient mental difficulties. Such a one ilifying as a social worker should be carefully selected and »uld possess the qualification of training and experience as 11 as temperamental fitness for the work. Better that no rker should be employed than one who is incompetent to •ry out the spirit and purpose for which the position is Dentistry Many patients of this hospital come to us with tooth conditions very bad. Many develop tooth troubles while with us. Bacteriological research has revealed the associa - tion between tooth infections and many physfcal difficulties. Its relation to some nervous afflictions as well as mental difficulties is quite probable. The state should provide a den - tist service for the wards. Improvements tA fire-proof addition to the male division of the hos - il has been constructed. The housing capacity of this icture will be 75 male patients. A sun porch has been ed to the male hospital building and a corridor connect - this with the new addition thereby securing communica - f corridors to every ward of the institution. New tunnels being constructed connecting the old kitchen to the new ition. A new laboratory and morgue building is being structed. An addition by extending the sun porch in the "B" building two additional stories has provided housing capacity in the woman's dormitory known as "B" building. Fans and Out Departments tThe farm has been very productive during the past bien - period. An abundance of alfalfa, fair crop of corn and toes have been produced. The garden has been produc - and has accomplished much toward lessening the ex-

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 245 pense of maintenance. The greenhouse has been unusually productive, beautiful flowers and plants have done much to cheer the wards of the institution. Our autumn flower carni - val held in the amusement hall won many compliments for our florist. The chicken industry has been rather interrupted by the serious illness of the man in charge during a period when the work was very important. We hope to accomplish better results during the next period. The cash fund of the institution derived from the main - tenance of patients, by the sale of hogs and some farm pro - ducts has enabled us to build the connecting corridors, furn - ish the new additions and remodel portions of the old kitchen together with various other improvements and the instal - lation of water heaters, steam fittings, etc. The old main building has been rewired and rendered safe from an elec - trical standpoint. The institution has been cut over on the circuit providing light from the penitentiary'. PLANS FOR THE FUTURE The general plan of the institution during the future should be to develop the industrial pursuits, library and amusements and to carry on some research work. Training school should be developed in accord with the universal plan adopted in institutions of this sort, having for its object the dual purpose of providing a nurse with training and supply - ing the State with an efficient individual. Salaries and wages should be so adjusted that one entering the service and se - curing the training could depend upon this special line of service as a life work, feeling assured that the recompense would be sufficient to provide for old age, thus enabling one to devote a life of service to the relief of suffering and the accomplishment of much to the State economically. The general repairs of the institution are in fair «on - dition. However, the plumbing in all of the old buildings is of the old type, poorly vented and new construction should replace the old. Provision should be made for illuminating the campus of the institution and the outside buildings. The out departments of the institution are in total darkness and

246 SECOND BIENNIAL REPORT OF t campus is in no way protected from trespassers and ; who have inclinations toward acts of vandalism. Sev - years ago I suggested the construction of a fence to protect the institution grounds from trespassers and to divert the stream of pedestrians passing through the hospital grounds into natural channels. I strongly recommend the construction of a fence and a lighting system. The housing at this time is so overtaxed and will con- inue to be overtaxed until additional buildings are provided, recommend the construction of new buildings to house two indred patients. I further recommend the construction of building to house one hundred employees. I recommend ie removal of the greenhouse from its present site on the ont campus to a point in the garden adjacent to the cen - al heating plant where the expense of heating may be much reduced. I recommend the construction of a new kitchen ran employees' dining room and the removal of the pres - unsafe, unsanitary and unsightly structure devoted to that use. Eitimatei of Appropriation* for 1917-18 Basing our estimates on the expenditures of the past period and estimating the population for the future period, we will require appropriations as follows: The cost per patient during the past biennial period has En approximately $16 per month. The number of patients the hospital at the present time is 761. During the next nnial period our population cannot be greatly increased lack of new structure. If an appropriation is made to con - uct a building and the same is made ready for use before the close of the biennial period our population might reach rt by the close of the period. I feel it is, therefore, safe figure on the basis of an average population of 800 pa- tients. Upon this basis we would require as follows : fficers' Salaries $19,700 Imployees' Wages 82,000 [aintenance 205,500 Total $307,200

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 247 The total appropriation for the biennial period should be as follows: For ordinary expenses including salaries, wages of officers and employees together with the mainten- ance consisting of board, clothing, fuel, furniture, hardware, kitchen and dining room supplies, drugs, books, instruments, telephone and telegraph, freight, express, library, stationary, postage, live stock, vehicle, harness, machinery, blacksmith - ing, religious services, amusement, burial, laundry, engine room, plumbing supplies, expense attending return of pa - tients and traveling expenses, building material, general re - pairs, plants, oils, glass, decorators' supplies, brick, cement, tree?, walks, curbing, seeds, plants, supplies for industrial departments, musical instruments, office equipment, hospital supplies and any incidental and necessary expense not spe - cifically mentioned incurred in the legitimate conducting of the affairs of the Nebraska Hospital for the Insane, the sum CONCLUSION In closing I wish to express my appreciation of the hearty co-operation received from His Excellency, the Gov- ernor of Nebraska, and your Honorable Board, collectively and individually, and also to express my appreciation of the co-operation of our efficient staff and co-workers in the institution who are largely responsible for the success attend- ing our efforts in the past biennial period. Lincoln, Nebraska, November SO, 1919. Respectfully, B. F. Williams, Superintendent.
